dataIdInfo.idCredit:
Created by the Center for Population Economics as part of the Historical Urban Ecological (HUE) data set, completed 2013. Primary funding for this project was provided by the National Institute on Aging of the National Institutes of Health under program project grant P01 AG10120.
For a complete list of citations and sources please refer to the "Baltimore Ward History" and "HUE Historical Shorelines" documents available from the Center for Population Economics.

idCitation.resTitle: CPE Historical Urban Ecological (HUE) Data Set - Baltimore Ward System 1883-1887

dataIdInfo.idAbs: The Center for Population Economics (CPE) has created a set of ward boundaries used by the above city and its departments between 1830 and 1930 for use with the Historical Urban Ecological (HUE) data set. These systems of ward boundaries were used for administrative and reporting purposes during the indicated time period. Each unique system in a given city's ward history reflects new annexations to that city, the creation of new wards, renumbering schemes, and/or explicit changes to existing ward boundaries. Shoreline geographies are representative of a point in time during a ward system's use that was generally applicable to the period, and have been digitized from georeferenced historical maps and other archival records. Those ward boundaries which followed historical street centerlines were derived from the HUE Street Centerline file for that city. Other boundaries were recreated from georeferenced historical maps and other archival records. More complete resources on individual cities are available on the CPE website.
dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.0.4322
dataIdInfo.idPurp: Ward and city boundaries used by the City of Baltimore and its municipal departments for the years 1883 through 1887.

Consts.useLimit: While the HUE data set is publicly available, users of the HUE data set must acknowledge in all published and unpublished reports based on these data that the source of the data is the Center for Population Economics. The program project is identified by the number P01 AG10120. Robert W. Fogel is the Principal Investigator. Users of the HUE data set must abide by the Public Access policy set forth by the National Institutes of Health (NIH). More information can be found at:http://publicaccess.nih.gov/. The temporal and horizontal spatial information present in these files is provided for the purposes of statistical analysis and historical spatial referencing only. No warranty, expressed or implied, is made with regard to the accuracy of the spatial, temporal, or attribute accuracy of the data. The HUE data set and GIS shapefiles are for research purposes only and are not suitable for high-precision measurement applications including but not limited to property ownership and transfers, engineering problems, or other uses that might require municipally commissioned survey data or highly accurate measurements of the earthâ€™s surface.
